snippet: After decades of decline from once-total control of the South, Democrats already had little left to lose before the election.
abstract: Republican rout in Southern states went well beyond the Senate races and down to the state level, smothering hopes for strong Democratic farm teams; after decades of decline from once-total control of South, Democrats already had little to lose before election, but party leaders say they have hope for future, tempered with realism about challenges.

byline.original: By CAMPBELL ROBERTSON and RICHARD FAUSSET
byline.contributor: Campbell Robertson reported from New Orleans, and Richard Fausset from Atlanta. Alan Blinder contributed reporting from Little Rock, Ark.

lead_paragraph: After decades of decline from once-total control of the South, Democrats already had little left to lose before the election.

headline.main: Swamped in a Red Surge, Southern Democrats Contemplate Their Rebuilding Plans
headline.print_headline: Swamped in a Red Surge, Southern Democrats Contemplate Their Rebuilding Plans
